bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, August 12, 1952

div1.p: Hench requests information about the naming of the Camp Lazear memorial. He plans to send her copies of Kelly's book on Reed, the Sternberg biography, and Senate Document 822. Hench advises her to get a copy of Carlos E. Finlay's book about his father.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, August 12, 1952
div1.opener:
August 12, 1952
Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas
Quinta San Jose
Calle Real
Quemados de Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Tina:
div1.p:
Not having heard from you the last couple of weeks, I suspect you are
away but I shall send this just the same. I would appreciate it greatly
if you would let me know what you hear or see in the papers about the
re-dedication and naming of Camp Lazear.

I had planned to send you three important items which you should have
as a permanent record in your home; the Senate Document, No. 822; a copy
of Doctor Kelly's book, Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever, and
a copy of the life of General Sternberg. These all give the official
records regarding Camp Lazear and I want you to have them with my compli-
ments. Since I have not heard from you, I have decided to hold up mailing
the books until I know that you are home because these books are quite
rare and I don't want them to go astray if you are away.

Incidentally, have you gotten a copy of the book of Dr. Charles E. Finlay
about his father? I would advise you to get a copy. The American edition
appeared in 1940, the Spanish edition in 1942. In the American edition,
on page 82, Doctor Finlay's son erroneously uses the name Asuncion Farm
instead of the Finca San Jose. But in his own handwriting he corrected
this in my copy and the matter is given correctly on page 80 of the Spanish
edition and speaks of the early experiments which his father did at the
Finca San Jose.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
